text: Imagine asking for a pay raise , when you are doing your job & 1/10 of Singaporean’s now are taking UPL , Retrenchment & Unemployed

answers.text: @__invalid_username w/o the frontliners, it will be even harder to recover from this pandemic
@__invalid_username if we dont let them know we care about them in a practical way, what is left for them to keep going? Yes, it's their job, but sometimes people can only take so much.

@zachalio I just think the gov should do more for the frontliners other than giving emotional support. Not many employers will happily raise their staffs pay w/o any prompting. Kodos to u for having the resilience to cope with increasing workload and job hazard, but it may not represent what the other frontliners feel. When I was still interning at the hospital b4 Dorsco Orange, I seen quite a lot of nurses are scared, sad and exhausted, the least we can do is for them to bring a little more salary home for their family members.

@__invalid_username I’m a frontliner (not medical staff tho) and tbh I’m feeling really fortunate I’m still employed and receiving full pay right now. While I will never say no to a pay raise or even hazard pay, I feel that if there are resources available (from the government) to help anyone, it shd go to those affected, loss of job or income, or those who are vulnerable. Of cos it is the frontliners’ employer’s duty to ensure that they are still well taken care of. If the employer chooses to reward on their own expense, yay to everyone.
@jeslynkinggg imagine the frontliners stopped working during this period of time.

text: At least tag the artist, especially since you edited his art, most likely without his permission @gudim_public

answers.text: @calistacyq its a meme🤦‍♂️,there’s no need to tag permission dumb fuck

text: Haha that's what I do all the time, underpay and overwork my workers, cheer for them and they will feel emotionally and psychologically better.
Sigh here we go again. Read this if you want to know why these "insignificant" things are important as well. https://www.instagram.com/p/B_b9sCNlAYK/?igshid=56zd1bln4in0

answers.text: @xxcurarexx underpay overworked and all we do is scream for them i mean it helps mentally but it doesnt help a lot like imagine working ur ass off and the government, instead of paying you more for your time they just get people to try and sing and shout and all that shit

@xxcurarexx Actually this also serves as a reminder for everyone to not just stop at the mass singing but also continue to care for them in the future to come, or else it is just a momentarily boosting of morale, but in the long term if people continue to look down on essential workers then the mass singing does not really help them

@xxcurarexx i think the problem isnt that they want to provide moral support. The problem is they want to provide ONLY moral support, and not active positive change. Singing NDP songs and cheering for healthcare workers will boost their morale to some extent, yes. Everybody appreciates being cheered on when theyre trying their hardest. But morale isnt always sufficient, thats the point people are trying to make

@ngshihan Hm alright, perhaps I might've went on a tangent about healthcare workers. I understand and agree on that. Essential workers need more support, especially with the rise of them being undermined by COVID even more so with how the government is handling the situation with regards to stopping the essential workers. But I still stand tho, with these kind of support and amidst sentiments online being that it 'distracts' us from important issues, i will argue that it unites us and helps us fight for the proper and necessary needs for Singaporeans. I hope. Cheers
@xxcurarexx good to give emotional support n all la.. nvr say shldnt give. but if u give emotional support only n not better working conditions as well then a bit fked up

@wakeupsingapore this is in the Philippines, but still relevant anyways. Why? Imagine, you're saving lives yet you are stigmatized and not appreciated at all, and hat's just demoralizing:  https://www.straitstimes.com/asia/stigmatisation-of-frontline-health-workers-appalling-inquirer these sing along help support our frontlije workers emotionally and psychologically, don't you feel happy and encouraged when you're playing in a sport and everyone is rooting for you at the sidelines? But fin, here's one closer to home; https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/covid19-tan-tock-seng-staff-porters-housekeepers-12651204 our healthcare workers are facing the virus head on. Any decent humans would want to feel like they're efforts are not in vain, that people are behind them, cheering for them amidst the grim reality. One more and I hope you actually read the articles; https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/coronavirus-people-pen-well-wishes-for-healthcare-staff-amid-outbreak. As a matter of fact, I can't emphasize this enough: we are all humans. Being pessimistic and negative is the last thing any decent social creature would want in a time where social distancing is heavily implemented. These measures, even if it looks insignificant, may mean something to someone else's lives. At the very least, it helps Singaporeans feel united. It's not like we're living in a void that once the songs over, nothing is done. In fact, we have seen a rise in people giving donations, many on the ground movements and issues shed light upon to raise awareness, and all by the very Singaporeans living here. This is just another measure at our disposal. We have to take our chances, and if it means singing to unite and feel like there's no hope lost, sure. Stop being pessimistic unnecessarily.

@xxcurarexx It's like a game, if morale is down, no amount of strength or armour or people will help win the battle. We need everything in this battle with COVID. this includes the will and determination by the people supporting our frontlije workers, financially, emotionally, mentally, and psychologically.

TLDR: we need psychological and mental and emotional support in these times of crisis as well. Even healthcare workers being trampled upon, intially being seen as COVID carriers. When we do these things, it boosts their morale, it makes them feel appreciated.
